Chapter 9, Section 4, Part 9: Discussing Karma. The sÅ«tra says that there are four kinds of karma, namely, there is karma with black black ripening, or there is karma with white white ripening, or there is karma with black and white black and white ripening, or there is karma that is neither black nor white.
Karma that can exhaust all karma without ripening, although the sÅ«tra briefly shows it, it does not explain it in detail. Now it should be explained, what are its characteristics?
Verse:
Based on the distinctions of black-black, etc., the four kinds of karma that are spoken of,
Bad form, wholesome in the desire realm, able to exhaust that which is without outflows,
One should know that they are called black, white, both black and white, and neither black nor white, in order.
Discussion:
The Buddha, based on the different natures and classes of the fruits of karma, and the distinctions between what is to be eliminated and what eliminates it, spoke of the four: black-black, etc.
All unwholesome actions are called black, because they are defiled black and have undesirable black results. Their retribution is also black, because it is undesirable.
Wholesome actions of the realm of form are called white, because they are not mixed with any unwholesome passions or unwholesome actions. Their retribution is also white, because it is desirable.
On what basis is it said that wholesome actions of the formless realm are excluded?
Some say that
in this discussion, the first is mentioned to indicate the last. Or, because the realm of form has desirable white and clear white that can be designated, it is called white.
The formless realm has desirable white but does not have clear white that can be designated, and therefore it is not called white.
Or, because the realm of form has two kinds of white natures, which are innate and produced, it is called white. A scripture says,
Either male or female, having accomplished good bodily actions, etc., after death he is reborn in a heaven of form, and experiences a form born of mind that is like white cloth or a clear night.
Or, in the realm of form, one is endowed with the three actions and the ten courses of action, but not so in the formless realm.

Yet a scripture says, â€œThe innumerable contemplations and the formless concentrations are all called action that is white with white retribution.â€ This is said generally because they are pure and have desirable retribution.
However, this scripture is not definitive, because it speaks of action in terms of the four aggregates and five aggregates of the upper realms.
Because retribution is manifested by action, that which is not action is also called action. This proves that this scripture is not definitive.
It is said that good action in the realm of desire is called black and white, because it is mixed with evil. Its retribution is also black and white, because it is mixed with undesirable results.
The names black and white are established on the basis of the continuity of action, not on the basis of its own nature.
Why is this?
Because there is no single action or single retribution that is black and also white, because these are mutually contradictory.
If this is so, then the results of evil action should be called white and black, because they are mixed with the results of good action.
This objection is unreasonable, because in the realm of desire, the power of frequent practice of evil subdues good, and therefore the result of suffering is mixed with the retribution of pleasure.

Good in the realm of desire is weak and has no power to subdue evil, and therefore the result of pleasure has no power to mix with the retribution of suffering. Therefore the result of evil karma is called pure black.
Other masters say:

Good karma in the realm of desire arises as black and white mixed, because of intention and performance. For this reason, the two names black and white are established, but the substance of one karma is neither good nor evil.
How is this?

For example, in order to deceive and harm another, one intends to make the other believe in oneself, and first deceitfully practices giving, even to the point of renouncing the world. This is called having a black intention but a white performance.

Or, a person, out of compassion, uses harsh words and physical force to stop a son or disciple from doing something that is not beneficial and to make him do something that is beneficial. This is called having a black means but a white end.
If this is so, then non-good should be called white and black, because, like good actions, it also arises from a mixture of white and black means and ends.
But this is not accepted, and the previous explanation is not erroneous.
The fourth kind of action is that which is able to eternally eliminate the first three kinds of action. This fourth kind of action is called pure, because it is not defiled.

It is not erroneous to say that it is not black, because it does not fall into the three realms of existence, and it is not erroneous to say that it has no retribution, because it eliminates retribution.
Since it is the highest truth of purity, why is it called not white?
The Buddha also said in the MahÄÅ›Å«nyatÄsÅ«tra:
The dharmas of the adepts are pure and white, and are entirely without sin.
The present treatise also says:
What are pure dharmas?
They are good dharmas and non-defiled indeterminate dharmas.
This is said with a hidden meaning, not with the sound of pure.
What is the hidden meaning?
It means that in this case, the fourth is established as the antidote to the previous three karmas. Do not let those who are to be converted give rise to such doubts:
How can purity here be the antidote to purity?
In order to show that the antidote is superior to what is to be countered, it is called non-pure based on the attraction of retribution, because it cannot attract pure retribution.
Or, because the dharmas of the stage of post-learner can be attained in the body that transcends all defilements, they are called purely white;
unlike the dharmas of the stage of learner, which cannot be attained in the body that transcends all defilements, and are therefore not called purely white.
Therefore, in that sÅ«tra, based on this meaning, the purely white sound is spoken of with regard to the dharmas of the stage of post-learner.
In this sÅ«tra, because uncontaminated karma is not in accordance with what is desirable, and also because it cannot attract white retribution, it is called non-white.
Do all pure actions exhaust the previous three kinds of actions?
No, they do not.
How is it?
The verse says:
In the four forbearances of the dharma of separation from desire, the first eight uninterrupted paths,
Twelve pure thoughts only exhaust pure black karma.
In the four meditations of separation from desire, the ninth uninterrupted thought,
One exhausts mixed black and white and pure black, and four cause pure white to be exhausted.
The treatise says:

In the path of seeing, the four forbearances of dharma knowledge of the four truths, and in the path of cultivation, in the state of separation from the defilements of the desire realm, the first eight uninterrupted paths of the noble path, which are accompanied by twelve thoughts, only exhaust pure black karma.

In the ninth uninterrupted path of the noble path accompanied by the separation from the defilements of the desire realm, one pure thought causes both black and white and pure black to be exhausted. At this time, because the wholesome karma of the desire realm is completely eliminated, the ninth unwholesome karma is also eliminated.
In the separation from the defilements of each of the four meditations, the ninth uninterrupted path is accompanied by pure thoughts.
These four only cause the pure white karma to be exhausted, because the remaining karmas have no retribution, are not the object of illumination, and are not discussed here.
Therefore, in this context, only the holy thoughts that accompany the uninterrupted path are said to be able to eternally exhaust the previous three contaminated karmas.
Although the exhaustion of all karmas is the ability of the holy wisdom, here the proximate antidote is spoken of.
Although bodily and verbal karmas are also proximate antidotes to the three, they are not said to be associated with wisdom.
Why is it that in all stages, contaminated good karma is only able to be severed by the final path and not by the others?
Because the good dharmas are not severed by their own nature, because that which has been severed may still appear in the present.

However, it is said that when the afflictions that take them as objects are exhausted, one is said to have severed those good dharmas, because at that time the good dharmas attain freedom from bondage.

For this reason, as long as there is still one category of afflictions that take them as objects remaining, the meaning of severance is not established, because at that time the good dharmas are still bound.
Verse:
Some say that karma to be experienced in hell is black, and the rest of the karma of the desire realm is black and white.
Some say that karma to be experienced in the desire realm and the realm of views is black and white, and the rest of the karma of the desire realm is black.
The treatise says:
The first and third [positions] both have different explanations.
Some other masters say:
Karma to be experienced in hell and karma to be experienced in the rest of the desire realm are called pure black karma and mixed black and white karma respectively.
This is because the retribution of hell is only produced by unwholesome karma, so karma to be experienced in hell is called pure black karma.

Except for hell, the rest of the retributions in the desire realm are produced by both wholesome and unwholesome karma, so karma to be experienced in the rest of the desire realm is called black and white karma.
This explanation has already been refuted, namely, because wholesome karma cannot be mixed with unwholesome karma.

Some other masters say:ğŸ”½Karma eliminated by the path of the desire realm and the realm of views, and the rest of the karma of the desire realm, are called pure black karma and mixed black and white karma respectively.

This is because karma eliminated by the path of the realm of views is not mixed with wholesome karma, so it is called pure black karma. Karma eliminated by the path of cultivation of the desire realm has both wholesome and unwholesome karma, so it is called mixed black and white karma.
This is unreasonable, because both the two kinds of actions are unable to produce retribution.

If you say that the three kinds of action mentioned in the above passage refer to action that has retribution and not to that which does not have retribution, then you should not specify that action is eliminated by the path of insight.
Also, strong action is definitely not overwhelmed by that which is weak. Therefore you should not say that unwholesome action eliminated by the path of cultivation is also called mixed.
You should not say that wholesome action in the realm of desire is stronger than unwholesome action and overwhelms bad action, because this is not admitted.
Why is this?
Because wholesome action in the realm of desire is not frequently practiced and is not capable of producing results for one kalpa.
A scripture speaks of three kinds of muni, and another scripture speaks of three kinds of purity, all of which are of body, speech, and mind. What are their characteristics?
The verse says,
The three kinds of muni are the three actions of body and speech of the post-learner,
and you should know that the three kinds of purity are the three good actions.
The Treatise says:

The unarisen bodily action is called the body muni, the unarisen verbal action is called the speech muni, and the unarisen mind is called the mind muni. The body of the mind muni is not the essence of mental action.
Why is it said that only in the form and consciousness aggregates are there these munis, and not in the other aggregates?
Other masters say:
Citing the last and the first, it is a classification that reveals that the middle also has this meaning.
According to the true meaning, the supreme truth muni has only the mind as its essence. Therefore a sutra says:
Because the mind is tranquil, sentient beings are tranquil.

This mind muni, because of the bodily and verbal actions being free from many evils, can be inferred. Mental action has no inferential function in it. Only the inferable and the inferential are combined to establish the muni.
Why are the munis only in the post-learners?
Because arhats are true munis, because the words of the afflictions are eternally tranquil.
The three kinds of good conduct of body, speech, and mind are also called the three kinds of pure and uncontaminated good conduct.
They are called pure because they are forever free of the defilements of evil conduct and passions.
How can contaminated good conduct be pure, since it is still defiled by the defilements of evil conduct and passions?
It is also called pure because it is temporarily free of the defilements of evil conduct and passions, or because it is able to induce the pure good conduct of the ultimate truth.

If you say that it is also able to induce the defilements of evil conduct and passions, because it is a condition as the equivalent and immediate antecedent of passions, then it should not be called pure. This is also unreasonable.
When a good mind arises, it is not the case that a defiled mind is generated as a proximate antecedent.

Uncontaminated dharmas do not arise immediately after a defiled mind, but uncontaminated dharmas can be induced by a good mind that is contaminated. Therefore contaminated good conduct is called pure, because it is favorable to the uncontaminated mind and can remove impurities. The reason for mentioning these two kinds of good conduct is to stop sentient beings from imagining that there is a wrong Muni and a wrong purity.
Also, a scripture says, â€œThere are three kinds of evil conduct,â€ and â€œThere are three kinds of good conduct,â€ all of which are conduct of body, speech, and mind. What are their characteristics?
Verse:
Evil conduct of body, speech, and mind are called the three kinds of evil conduct;
The three kinds of good conduct are the opposite of these.
Treatise:
All unwholesome bodily and verbal actions, the proximate and fundamental stages before and after, and unwholesome volition are respectively called evil conduct of body, speech, and mind.
However, evil conduct of mind is of three kinds, namely, non-volition, greed, anger, and wrong views.
Isn't it also said in the scriptures that greed, etc. are called mental actions? How can it be said now that greed, anger, and wrong views are not mental actions?
Because they are the provisions for action, they are also called action, just as the provisions for defilements are also called defilements, etc.
How do we know that greed, etc. are not mental actions?
Because of the scriptures and correct reasoning.
As for the scriptures, it is said in the scriptures:
Greed, hatred, and wrong views are the conditions and accumulations of karma.
Therefore, we know that greed, etc., are not the nature of karma itself.
Moreover, a sutra says:
The expressions those who love and those who desire refer to mental actions.
Therefore, we know that love is not the substance of mental action itself.
The other [two roots] should be understood in the same way. Do not think that karma is the same as the accumulation of karma. Therefore, a sutra says:
Love and karma are different.
However, the author of the treatise says:
If we admit that afflictions are the same as mental actions, what fault is there?
Such an admission contradicts a previous sutra and later correct reasoning. Isn't this a great fault?

If it is said that just as it is said that greed causes the mind to create evil conduct, although this sutra says that greed is the cause and condition of mental evil conduct, it is not denied that greed is included in mental evil conduct.
In the same way, although it is said that love is the cause of karma, this love should also not be karma.
That example is not the same. This sutra does not say that love causes the mind to create manifest karma.

For example, as it is said that craving causes the mind to create evil actions, this sÅ«tra does not say that craving causes the mind to produce manifest actions. How can one cite that to exemplify this sÅ«tra, proving that the cause of manifest action is also action due to craving?
As the sÅ«tra says that all delusion is ignorance, this sÅ«tra only shows that delusion is the substance of ignorance, and that apart from delusion there is no ignorance.
In the same way, this sÅ«tra says that all seeking is craving, and that all craving is manifest mental action.
The distinction of characteristics has already been made clear.
If it is not seeking, it is not craving. If it is not manifest, it is also not mental action, except for provisional designation, then there is no fault.
Mental action is called manifest, as explained above.
What is the correct principle?
If afflictions are themselves action, then the distinctions of the twelve links of dependent arising, the three hindrances, and so forth would be nonexistent.
Therefore, we know that craving, etc., are not action, because they are despised by the wise and because they are able to attract undesirable results.
These actions are evil, and therefore they are called evil conduct. The three kinds of good conduct should be understood in the opposite sense.
That is, all good conduct of body and speech, the proximate and the fundamental, and all good volition are, respectively, called good conduct of body, speech, and mind.
However, good conduct of mind is of three kinds: noncraving, nonhatred, and right views, because they are praised by the wise and because they attract desirable results.
These are good conduct, and therefore they are called good conduct.
Even though right views and wrong views do not benefit or harm others, they are good or evil because they are the roots of good and evil conduct.
Also, the scriptures speak of ten kinds of courses of action that are either good or evil. What are their characteristics?
The verse states:
The so-called ten courses of action are included in good and evil conduct.
Their natures are the gross forms of good and evil, as appropriate.
The treatise states:
Among the previously mentioned evil and good conduct, the coarse and obvious ones are included as the ten courses of action.

As appropriate, the good ones include the previously mentioned good conduct, and the unwholesome courses of action include the previously mentioned evil conduct. What kinds of evil and good conduct are not included?
The preparatory and subsequent actions, etc., are not included because they are not coarse and obvious.

As for the ten unwholesome courses of action, if the evil bodily actions cause sentient beings to lose their lives, lose their wealth, lose their wives and concubines, etc., they are called courses of action because they cause one to be far removed from them.
If the evil verbal actions are even more serious faults, they are called courses of action because they cause one to be far removed from them.
If the evil mental actions are grave greed, ill-will, etc., they are called courses of action because they cause one to be far removed from them.
The preparatory and subsequent actions, as well as the other faults that are less serious, and unwholesome volition, are all not courses of action.

In the good paths of action, the good paths of action of body do not include a part of the good practices of body, namely, the preparatory and subsequent actions and the other good actions of body, such as abstaining from drinking alcohol, giving, etc.
The good paths of action of speech do not include a part of the good practices of speech, namely, affectionate speech, etc.
The good paths of action of mind do not include a part of the good practices of mind, namely, all good thoughts.
Are the first seven paths of action necessarily both with and without manifest action?
No, it is not so.
How is it?
Verse:
The six bad ones definitely have no manifest action, and he himself commits two in sexual misconduct;
The seven good ones have two in rebirth, and in the heavens there is only no manifest action.
Discussion:
Among the seven bad paths of action, the first six definitely have both with and without manifest action, namely killing, etc., except for sexual misconduct.
If one sends others to do it, when one reaches the fundamental stage, manifest action arises.
If one personally commits the six karmic paths, then all six have both indication and non-indication.

This is because when one generates indication, the other person may die immediately or die later, the same as when one sends an emissary. When the fundamental [karmic path] is completed, there is only non-indication.
Only sexual misconduct necessarily has both kinds, because it must be completed by one's own body, and cannot be done by sending another person, like one's own joy.
If the seven good karmic paths arise from precepts, they must all have both indication and non-indication, because the morality of precepts necessarily relies on indication.

The restraint included in the absorptions and the undefiled [restraints] is called arisen from concentration. This [restraint] only has non-indication, because it can only arise based on the power of the mind.
Are the preparatory and subsequent actions the same as the fundamental [karmic path]?
No, it is not so.ğŸ”½
How is it?
The verse says:
The preparatory [karmic path] definitely has indication, and may or may not have non-indication.
The subsequent [karmic path] is the opposite of this.
The treatise says:

The preparatory action of the path of action necessarily has manifest action. In this state, unmanifest action may or may not exist. If it is produced by a strong, intense defilement or a pure mind, then it has unmanifest action; if it is not like this, then it does not exist.
The subsequent action reverses the above and definitely has or does not have unmanifest action. In this state, manifest action may or may not exist.
The second moment of unmanifest action is the beginning and is called subsequent action. Therefore it definitely exists.
If at that time one produces a subsequent action, then it also has manifest action; if it is not like this, then it does not exist.
In this meaning, how are the states of preparatory action, root, and subsequent action established?

First, in the case of killing, which is unwholesome, when a butcher is about to kill, he first gives rise to the mind of killing, seeks a price, buys a sheep, takes his own provisions, travels far, visits the place of the shepherd, touches it, pays the price, leads it back, ties it up, fattens it, takes it to the slaughterhouse, holds a knife, seeks a vulnerable spot, cuts and stabs its body, until its life is not yet ended, all of which are called preparatory action.
The vijÃ±apti and avijÃ±apti of this moment are called the fundamental path of action of killing.
After this moment, the avijÃ±apti of killing continues without interruption and is called the subsequent action of killing.
And later, when the skin is removed, the meat is cut, washed, weighed, sold, and the profit is used to support oneself and oneâ€™s relatives, these vijÃ±aptis are also called subsequent actions.
The three parts of killing sheep are like this. The other forms of immorality should be explained according to their nature.

The three parts of the action of taking what has not been given are as follows. When a thief is about to steal, he first gives rise to the intention to steal, sends someone, or goes himself to spy on the location of the otherâ€™s property, goes to steal it, eats and drinks, packs his belongings, takes his tools, secretly goes to the otherâ€™s house, breaks through the wall, climbs a ladder, enters by some means, moves slowly, extends his hand, and gropes for the otherâ€™s property. All of this before the property is removed is called the preparatory action.
When the property is just being removed, the vijÃ±apti and avijÃ±apti of this moment are called the fundamental path of action.
After this moment, all the manifest actions such as the possession of the non-manifest action, taking out of the treasury, and enjoyment, etc., are called subsequent action.

As for the three parts of the action of sexual misconduct, for example, a man first arouses a mind of love for anotherâ€™s wife and is about to commit an impropriety. He sends someone to look at her, arranges a matchmaker to go back and forth, adorns himself and goes to her, speaks and laughs with her, holds and touches her. Before the matter is accomplished, it is all called the preparatory action.
When the matter is just completed, the manifest and unmanifest actions in this moment are called the fundamental path of action.
There is an interpretation that the completion is the entry into the orifice.
Other masters say:
It is the emission of semen.
After this moment, the non-manifest action and the manifest actions such as holding and touching, and the words of regret, etc., are all called subsequent action.

As for the three parts of the action of lying, first, a certain type of person who skillfully deceives in order to seek wealth and live off it, first accepts a request and promises to give false testimony. He then goes to the assembly with a deceptive intention and describes himself as a reliable witness, saying, I am neither an enemy nor a relative of the parties. I know that among all evils there is none worse than lying, and I know that among all good things there is none better than speaking the truth. Since I have no desire for either party, how could I unjustly bear the poison of a thorn? I am only afraid that the honest and upright will be falsely accused and punished.
Before becoming a witness, all this is called preparation.

If, when facing the assembly, he utters words with a contrary thought, falsely claiming to see what he does not see, and the deceived party understands, then at that moment the manifest and unmanifest actions are called the fundamental path of action.
Some say it is only accomplished when the deceived party confirms it.
If so, then there should be no lying to sages. However, since the fault of lying to sages is very grave, we should understand that the previous explanation is correct.
After this moment, the manifest action and the acquisition of wealth and benefits to support one's relatives are all called subsequent action.

The three parts of the action of divisive speech: First, a certain type of person, in order to destroy the mind of another, sends a messenger to convey a message or goes in person, pretending to be close in order to make the other person believe their words. Before destroying the other person, it is all called preparation.
The manifest and unmanifest action of uttering divisive speech at the moment the other person understands is called the fundamental path of action.
Other masters say:
It is only accomplished when the other person is destroyed.

If that were so, then the deep and solid friendship of the noble ones would be difficult to destroy, and there should be no offense of divisive speech that destroys the noble ones. However, the offense incurred by destroying the noble ones is extremely grave. Therefore, the previous explanation should be understood as correct.
After this moment, the manifest action and the manifest action of the present destruction, which has no intention of reconciliation, are all called subsequent action.

The three parts of the action of coarse speech: when a certain person is about to utter coarse speech, he arouses a mind of anger, clenches his fists, stamps his feet, raises his eyebrows, glares, gnashes his teeth, moves his lips, and before he utters speech, all this is called the preparatory action.
When he actually utters coarse speech and the other person understands, the action of the present moment that manifests and is not yet manifested is called the fundamental path of action.
Other masters say:
It is only completed when the other person is offended.

If this were so, then if one reviles a sage who is endowed with the power of patience, there should be no offense, but since the offense of reviling a sage is very grave, we know that the former explanation is correct.

After this moment, the action of the present moment and the subsequent action of the present moment and the subsequent action of the nonmanifest action and the coarse speech that repeats the offense are all called subsequent action.

The three parts of the action of frivolous speech: when a certain person arouses a frivolous mind, he first takes the property of others, collects various frivolous discourses, brings frivolous implements to an assembly, and utters frivolous speech in front of others. All this is called the preparatory action.
The moment of the initial expression of the words of playfulness and joy is the path of the root itself.
After this moment, the subsequent expression of words and the acquisition of wealth and its use, storage, and so on are all called subsequent action.
Other masters say:
The moment when greed, hatred, and false views are present is called the path of action. Therefore there is no distinction of preparatory action and subsequent action.
Those who say this also have three parts, because there is an unwholesome volition that can be the prior and subsequent companion of greed, hatred, and so on.
Moreover, the various paths of action may mutually be preparatory and subsequent action for each other.

For example, there are those who wish to harm an enemy and devise various plans to create the conditions for killing, either killing living beings to pray for assistance, or stealing others' possessions to finance the killing, or having sex with their spouse to have them kill their husband, or knowing that the enemy's close friend is strong and their own strength is weak, and killing is difficult to accomplish, therefore first using the four verbal faults towards the enemy's close friend to destroy their mind, causing them to have no intention of rescuing the enemy, skillfully enticing them to join one's own faction, or having covetous thoughts towards their possessions, or giving rise to anger towards them, or giving rise to wrong views to nurture the killing karma, and then killing.

Having killed them, at a later time they execute their relatives, seize their possessions, and have sex with those they love, and so on, until later giving rise to manifest wrong views. This is called the karmic path of killing, with the ten evil karmic paths as the preparatory and subsequent actions. The other karmic paths should be understood as appropriate.
Other masters say:
Greed, etc., should not be able to be the instigation, because the instigation is not accomplished merely by the arising of the mind, because the action has not yet been done.

According to this explanation, although greed, etc., are not the nature of the action that is done, when they arise taking an object, they are not without power and efficacy. Because they have power and efficacy, they are called instigation, because they lead to the generation of the paths of action.

Now we should discuss this in detail. As explained above, when the one who performs the action dies immediately after the initial performance of the action, the manifest and unmanifest action of that moment are called the fundamental path of action of killing. This should not be reasonable.

Why is this?ğŸ”½When the one who is killed is in the state of the intermediate existence after death, can the manifest and unmanifest action of the killer in that moment be the path of action, or is it after death that it becomes the path of action?

If the one who is killed is in the intermediate existence after death, and the path of action is accomplished by the killer, although the previous statement seems to be without error, it definitely contradicts the meaning of the tenet.

If the one who is killed and the one who kills both die at the same time, then it should be said that the one who kills accomplishes the path of action of killing, because it is accepted that the path of action of killing is accomplished even if the one who is killed still exists.

When the one who kills is in the state of death, at that time the one who is killed is called dead. Then the one who kills should be said to obtain this one moment of the path of action of killing. However, the school does not accept that when the one who is killed dies at the same time, the sin of the path of action is accomplished.
If the path of action is accomplished only after the other has died, then what was said before is unreasonable.

When the one who is killed is in the process of dying, it cannot be said that the life of the other has already been cut off. How can it be said that at that moment of the other's death, the manifest and unmanifest actions are the fundamental path of action of killing?
But now it is said that the path of action of killing is accomplished only after the other has died.
In this way, the two alternatives should be carefully examined and determined. It is certain that the path of action is accomplished only after the other has died.

The term â€œat the moment of deathâ€ in the above passage refers to the past, but is expressed in the present tense, just as when it is said that a great king has arrived from afar, and someone asks, â€œWhere has he come from?â€

Or, it is said that the effect is provisionally attributed to the cause, because at the moment when the victim dies, the manifest action of the killer is effective in killing, and the manifest action of the path of action is not. The manifest action of the path of action continues to arise from the preparatory action, and because it is drawn by that, it is called the effect of the preparatory action.

However, the cause has a superior function in killing, and therefore the effect is provisionally attributed to the cause. In reality, it is not the path of action that is said to be the path of action.
Isnâ€™t it the case that at this time the manifest action is effective, and so should it be established as the path of action?
It is not necessary to have the ability in order to be a path of action, lest unmanifest action lose the name of path of action.
What function does it have in killing?
Just as unmanifest action, so too should manifest action be.
Also, it is not reasonable to establish the preparatory manifest action as the path of action, because the life of the sentient being to be killed still exists at the time of death.

The preparatory manifest action and the life of the being to be killed must cease simultaneously. After death, there is no life of the same kind. In one moment, neither manifest nor unmanifest action can constitute the path of action.
The manifest action of the subsequent moment has no ability to kill. It is not even killing, let alone a sin.
Only the unmanifest action should be called the path of action. Although it has no ability to kill, it is the result of killing.
Isn't it reasonable that the subsequent manifest action is also like this? Because the manifest action of killing is the cause that gives rise to it.
That is to say, when the preparatory action and the completion of the result occur simultaneously, these two together constitute the fundamental path of action.

Although these two have no ability to end the life of another, they have the function of grasping an undesirable future result, because the intention to kill is fulfilled. Therefore it is called the path of action of killing.

Is there already killing of living beings, but the killing has not yet ceased?
It is said:
Yes, for example, when one has already taken life, but the preparatory action has not yet ceased.
What is the meaning of this statement?
Here the meaning is that when killing, there are three kinds of preparatory actions for killing:
First, only by the internal, such as punching and striking;
Second, only by the external, such as throwing stones and so on;
Third, by both, such as wielding a knife and so on.

Among these three kinds of preparatory actions for killing, although the life of the being to be killed has already been cut off, the thought of the killer has not yet been removed, so the preparatory action for killing is not abandoned.
For this reason, the original treatise says:
Just as when one has already taken life, the preparatory action has not yet ceased.
The term killing is used to refer to the preparatory action of killing, so it can be said that the killing has not yet ceased.

because the thought of the performance of the act of killing has not yet ceased in the killer, and the thought that the object to be killed has already died has not yet arisen.

Because the performance of the act of killing by the killer is still not yet ceased at the time of the next moment after the death existence of the object to be killed, and for many moments after that, therefore it should be said that it is the subsequent action and the fundamental action.

Do all the paths of action at the time of culmination all arise from the three roots?
The Buddha said this, that not all the paths of action at the time of culmination all arise from the three roots, because there are differences in the preparatory stages.
What are the differences?
The verse says:
The preparatory stages arise from the three roots, because they immediately give rise to those,
and greed and so forth arise from the three roots.
The treatise says:
When the preparatory stages of the unwholesome paths of action arise, each arises from the three unwholesome roots. This is said based on their original arising.

The preparatory stages of killing that arise from greed are like those who greedily desire their teeth, hair, or body parts, or in order to obtain wealth, or for the sake of entertainment, or in order to rescue a friend or themselves, and thus give rise to the preparatory stages of killing out of greed.
That which arises from hatred is like the case of one who, in order to eliminate an enemy, gives rise to an angry mind and performs the action of killing.
That which arises from delusion is like the case of the Persians who say:

If one causes one's aged and sick parents to end their lives, one then gives rise to supreme merit, because one causes them to be liberated from present suffering and they newly attain a superior body with sharp faculties.
Also, they say that killing in a sacrifice to the Dharma is permissible.
Also, kings and others, relying on the laws of the world, punish enemies and eliminate evildoers, thinking that they thereby create great merit and perform the action of killing.
Also, non-Buddhists say:
Snakes, scorpions, bees, and others are poisonous and harmful to humans, so killing them brings merit.
Sheep, deer, water buffalo, and other animals are originally intended for food, so killing them is not a sin.
Also, due to wrong views, one kills living beings. The preparatory actions in these cases all arise from delusion.

Taking what is not given that is done through the influence of craving is, for example, stealing anotherâ€™s property in order to obtain wealth, honor, or fame, or in order to save your own life or the life of a friend.
Stealing that is done through the influence of hatred is, for example, stealing anotherâ€™s property in order to harm an enemy.

Discussion:

The preparatory, basic, and subsequent actions of all wholesome courses of action all arise from the roots of wholesomeness that are non-greed, non-hatred, and non-delusion, because the three stages of wholesome actions are all that which is produced by wholesome minds, and because wholesome minds are necessarily associated with these three roots of wholesomeness.
What are the characteristics of these three stages of wholesome actions?
It is said that they are far removed from the three stages of unwholesome actions, and the three stages of wholesome actions should be understood as being wholesome.

For example, when a novice monk receives full ordination, he enters the ordination platform, bows to the assembly of fully ordained monks, sincerely speaks to request the preceptor, and even up to the first announcement and second karman, all of these are called the preparatory stage of wholesome courses of action.
In the instant of completing the third karman, the manifest and unmanifest actions are called the basic course of action.

From this point on, up to the explanation of the four foundations, and the subsequent continuation of the manifest and unmanifest actions based on the previous characteristics, are all called subsequent actions.
As explained above, not all karmic paths are completed by the three roots. It should be explained by which roots which karmic paths are completed.

Wrong views are completed by delusion, because only the most extreme delusion can manifest them.

It is admitted that the three, namely, false speech, malicious speech, and frivolous speech, are completed by any one of the three roots, because when greed, hatred, etc., are present, each can cause the completion of these three.
The paths of action of greed and hatred are the roots of greed and hatred. How can it be said that they are completed by greed and hatred?

When the path of action of sexual misconduct is produced, there is certainly the root of greed that can complete it. When the paths of action of greed and hatred are produced, there is no greed or hatred that can complete them. Therefore it must be said that the three, namely, greed, hatred, and false views, are each completed by the root of delusion, because these three are not produced in those who are not deluded.
Other masters offer the following explanation:
It is said that these dharmas are completed by these roots because when their natures are produced, they are paths of action.
This explanation is offered because they have exhausted the reasoning. In reality, when greed, etc., are actually present, there is the root of delusion that can complete them.

If this is so, then wrong views should not be due to delusion, because the delusion associated with wrong views is not strong.

No, because the delusion that occurs with wrong views is strong, because at that time there is no other unwholesome root. Wrong views are not an unwholesome root, and therefore the delusion that occurs with it is superior as a root.

If this is so, then craving, etc., should not be due to delusion, because craving and hatred are roots and superior, and the delusion that occurs with them is weak. It should not be said that the paths of action of craving and hatred are completed by delusion.

There is no other faculty that can ultimately grasp greed, etc. The substance of the self cannot assist the self, so how can it be said that the self ultimately grasps the self?
Therefore, it is not wrong to say that delusion ultimately grasps.

As explained above, the four types of karmic paths arise in the four places of sentient beings, etc., in order, three, three, one, and three.

The three beginning with killing arise in the realm of sentient beings, the three beginning with stealing arise in the realm of objects, and only wrong view arises in the realm of names and forms. Lying, malicious speech, and frivolous speech arise in the realm of names, etc.
By what is the path of action of killing established?
It is established by the preparatory action and by the completion of the result. If either of these two parts is missing, one does not incur the fundamental transgression of killing.
Can there be a killer who performs the preparatory action of killing and brings the result to completion, yet who does not incur the transgression of killing?
Yes, there can.
How is this?
A verse says:
If they die together or before, there is no path of action because the basis is different.
The treatise says:

If the killer performs the preparatory action of killing with the definite intention to kill another, but dies either at the same time as the being to be killed or before, then the killer does not establish the path of action.
Why is this?

Because the life of the one who is killed is still present, and it is not possible for the killer to be touched by the sin of killing, because the life of the one who is killed has not yet been cut off.
It is not the case that the one who is able to kill, whose life has already ended, can obtain the sin of killing, because a different basis is born.

That is to say, the body that is the basis of the effort to kill has now been cut off. Although there is a different type of body that is born in the same continuum, it is not the basis of sin. This has never previously given rise to the effort to kill, and it is not reasonable that it should complete the path of killing.

If this is so, then the question here is unreasonable. Since the body that is the basis of the effort to kill is not able to cause the completion of the fruit of killing, then one of the two parts is missing. How can this aggregate be in the mind, and can it be asked whether there is a killer who gives rise to the effort to kill and causes the completion of the fruit?

If it is said that in this case, it is said that this gives rise to the effort and this completes the fruit in terms of a single continuum, then it should also be touched by the sin of killing, because it is admitted that what is born before and after is a single continuum.
Also, the reason you have stated has no power to prove your thesis, because the one who kills and the one who dies are not the same.

That is, even if the one who kills is alive, there is still moment-to-moment change and birth of different states, and the action does not immediately bring about the completion of the result. If you say that after death the continuity is different and therefore different from the one who is alive, then you are still lacking one part of your thesis.
This question is unreasonable.
This question is reasonable, because the reason has the power to prove.

Because there is a difference in meaning.

Is there a single continuity that initiates the action of killing and also brings about the completion of the result, but that one is not touched by the sin of killing?
Since the one who is born before and the one who is born after are the same continuity, and one part is not lacking, the one who answered later answered this way:

Because the body and continuity that are born before and after are the results of different actions and are born with different bases, the one born before is not touched by the sin committed by the one born after.
